title: The great detox - largest ever ban of toxic chemicals announced by EU
description: Thousands of the most notorious chemicals will be rapidly banned in Europe, the European Commission announced today, as part of the Zero-pollution goal in the EU Green Deal. The European Environmental Bureau (EEB) welcomed the move. If implemented, the action will be the largest ever regulatory removal of authori ...
cleaned_text: If implemented, the action will be the largest ever regulatory removal of authorised chemicals anywhere and covers chemicals that environmental, consumer and health groups have fought against for decades. The plan announced today, called the [Restrictions Roadmap](https://ec.europa.eu/docsroom/documents/49734?fbclid=IwAR0Ftb0aCg9_umH4lMvPBAuwekVQZiqGrL4jnOD7urUYAwz3nT6o8FHUd8E), is a political commitment to use existing [laws](https://echa.europa.eu/regulations/reach/legislation) to ban all flame retardants, chemicals that are frequently linked to cancer, and all bisphenols, widely used in plastics but which disrupt human hormones. It will also ban all forms of PVC, the least recyclable plastic that contains large amounts of toxic additives, and restrict all PFAS 'forever chemicals', plus around 2,000 harmful chemicals found in baby diapers, pacifiers and childcare products. European officials are unhappy that some 12,000 chemicals known to cause cancer, infertility, reduce vaccine effectiveness and generate other health impacts are still widely found in products, including sensitive categories like baby nappies and pacifiers. Officials consider the roadmap a rapid first step in an EU [chemical strategy](https://ec.europa.eu/environment/strategy/chemicals-strategy_en), with more fundamental [changes](https://eeb.org/chemical-detox-plan-for-europe-announced/) coming later, notably starting [in late 2022](https://ec.europa.eu/environment/chemicals/reach/reach_revision_chemical_strategy_en.htm). Some chemicals on the roadmap list were already facing EU restrictions, but most are new. The banning [process](https://echa.europa.eu/registry-of-restriction-intentions/-/dislist/details/0b0236e18323a25d) for all chemicals on the list will begin within two years. All substances will be gone by 2030, the EEB estimates. Industry raised a " [storm of protest](https://chemicalwatch.com/343273/storm-of-protest-hits-eu-roadmap-proposals-for-restrictions-on-groups-of-chemicals)" over early drafts of the plans and is expected to try to water them down. Chemicals make up the fourth largest industrial sector in the EU, with firms owned by some of Europe's [richest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Ratcliffe) and most [powerful](https://www.politico.eu/article/ngos-cry-foul-on-deza-chemical-company-linked-to-czech-prime-minister-andrej-babis-echa/) men. Industry association CEFIC [acknowledged](https://cefic.org/media-corner/newsroom/upcoming-eu-chemical-legislation-puts-europes-fourth-largest-manufacturing-industry-at-crucial-crossroads/) in December that as many as 12,000 chemicals, present in 74% of consumer or professional products, have properties of serious health or environmental concern. EU member governments unanimously [support](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48827/st06941-en21.pdf) the roadmap, although Italy is opposing (see [pages 3-5](https://circabc.europa.eu/ui/group/a0b483a2-4c05-4058-addf-2a4de71b9a98/library/e42df53d-345a-42a8-a88b-8209c5fa8737/details)) measures to ban PVC plastics. The EEB [frequently](https://eeb.org/toxic-shock-health-officials-block-progress-on-chemical-safety/) [criticises](https://eeb.org/press-release-sev-report/) European chemical controls for being too slow and [favouring business](https://eeb.org/named-major-brands-breaking-eu-chemical-safety-law/) interests over health and the environment. EEB chemicals policy manager Tatiana Santos said: "What Von der Leyen's Commission has announced today opens a new chapter in facing down the growing threat from harmful chemicals. This 'great detox' promises to improve the safety of almost all manufactured products and rapidly lower the chemical intensity of our schools, homes and workplaces. It is high time for the EU to turn words into real and urgent action" An estimated [200,000 chemicals](https://echa.europa.eu/information-on-chemicals/cl-inventory-database) are used in Europe. Global chemicals sales [more than doubled](https://www.unep.org/resources/report/global-chemicals-outlook-ii-legacies-innovative-solutions) between 2000 and 2017 and are expected to double again [by 2030](https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/27651/GCOII_synth.pdf). By volume, [three quarters](https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Chemicals_production_and_consumption_statistics#Total_production_of_chemicals) of chemicals produced in Europe are hazardous. Scientists recently [declared](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/18/chemical-pollution-has-passed-safe-limit-for-humanity-say-scientists?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other) that chemical pollution had crossed a planetary boundary, while last month a UN environment [report](https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/pollution-causing-more-deaths-than-covid-action-needed-says-un-expert-2022-02-15/) found that chemical pollution is causing more deaths than Covid-19. Daily exposure to a mix of toxic substances is linked to rising [health](https://www.who.int/ipcs/publications/chemicals-public-health-impact/en/), [fertility](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6396757/), [developmental](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laneur/article/PIIS1474-4422(13)70278-3/fulltext) threats, as well as the collapse of [insect, bird](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/oct/18/warning-of-ecological-armageddon-after-dramatic-plunge-in-insect-numbers) and [mammal](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/sep/27/orca-apocalypse-half-of-killer-whales-doomed-to-die-from-pollution) populations. Some [700](https://www.theworldcounts.com/challenges/toxic-exposures/polluted-bodies/chemicals-in-the-human-body/story) industrial chemicals are found in humans today that were not present in our grandparents. Doctors describe babies as born " [pre-polluted](https://www.ohchr.org/en/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=23788&LangID=E)". Official [polling](https://ec.europa.eu/commfrontoffice/publicopinion/index.cfm/survey/getSurveydetail/instruments/special/surveyky/2257) finds 84% of Europeans worried about the health impact of chemicals in products and 90% about their impact on the environment. Traditionally, the EU regulates chemicals one by one, an approach that has failed to keep up with industrial development of a new chemical every [1.4 seconds](https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/28186/GCOII_PartI.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y). The EU has banned around 2,000 hazardous chemicals over the last 13 years, more than any other world region. But these restrictions apply to very few products, such as cosmetics and toys. Roughly the same substances will now be banned from childcare items, a larger product group than toys or cosmetics. In addition, most other chemical groups targeted in the roadmap will apply to many product groups, greatly expanding regulatory impact. The EEB estimates that the roadmap will lead to roughly 5,000 to 7,000 chemicals being banned by 2030. The roadmap will step up a group approach to regulating chemicals, where the most harmful member of a chemical family defines legal restrictions for the whole family.
